population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on pesticide analysis in fruits and vegetables)

study_goal: To evaluate the impact of a preschool-based nutrition education program on young children's willingness to consume fruits and vegetables.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased children's willingness to consume vegetables (edamame, cauliflower, and red pepper) but did not affect fruit consumption. Greater changes in vegetable consumption occurred in the intervention group compared to the comparison group.
population_specificity: Three- to five-year-old children in preschool classrooms serving low-income families in the Denver metro area.
effective_dosage: Twelve 'hands on' nutrition education lessons delivered during the school year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test a family-centered, media literacy-oriented intervention to improve fruit and vegetable consumption and nutrition knowledge among children aged 9-14 and their parents.
results_summary: The intervention improved parents' use of nutrition labels, increased the ratio of healthy to unhealthy food in the home, and boosted youth's fruit and vegetable consumption. It also enhanced media literacy skills and family communication about food.
population_specificity: Parent-child dyads (N = 189), with children aged 9-14 years, including Latinx families.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ultrasonic technology in extending the storage time and maintaining the quality of postharvest fruits and vegetables.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasonic technology effectively improves preservation by removing pesticide residues, cleaning, sterilizing, and inactivating enzymes, though it may cause tissue and cell damage. Combining ultrasound with conventional methods further enhances preservation.
population_specificity: Postharvest fruits and vegetables.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary intake of pesticide residues from conventionally-grown fruits and vegetables affects fecundability (per cycle probability of conception) in women attempting to conceive.
results_summary: The study found no appreciable association between intake of high- or low-pesticide residue fruits and vegetables and fecundability in the full sample or among women trying to conceive for <3 cycles. However, among women trying for 3-6 cycles, both high- and low-pesticide residue intakes were inversely related to fecundability, suggesting potential reverse causation bias.
population_specificity: Women aged 21-45 years attempting to conceive without fertility treatment, enrolled in the Pregnancy Study Online (PRESTO) cohort.
study_duration: Up to 12 months or until reported conception

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of fruits and vegetables vouchers on food security among disadvantaged households in a Paris suburb.
results_summary: The study found that providing vouchers for fruits and vegetables significantly decreased food insufficiency in the intervention group after one year, while the control group showed no change. No association was found between food consumption and food security status.
population_specificity: Disadvantaged households from a Paris suburb experiencing food insecurity.
effective_dosage: Not specified (vouchers for fruits and vegetables over one year).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a structural and social food store intervention on promoting fruit and vegetable (FV) availability, placement, and promotions in Latino/Hispanic-focused tiendas.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased the total number of FV promotions and promotions outside the produce department, but no changes were observed in product availability or placement. The study suggests that modifying promotions in small stores is feasible and measurable.
population_specificity: Latino/Hispanic-focused food stores (tiendas)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of cultural immersion on children's willingness to try fruits and vegetables (FV) and assess FV intake in different camp settings.
results_summary: The study found an increase in willingness to try FV across all camp types, though no significant differences were observed among camps. The feasibility of using existing community programs for dietary behavior research was demonstrated.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-12 years in Guam, attending summer camps with varying cultural exposure levels.
study_duration: Duration of the summer camp programs (exact length not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the utility of the Information-Motivation-Behavioral Skills (IMB) model in explaining adolescents' fruits and vegetables consumption.
results_summary: The study found that fruits and vegetables-related information and motivation were positively related to adolescents' consumption, with behavioral skills partially mediating this relationship for information and personal motivation (specifically preferences).
population_specificity: Adolescents (N=1646) from a national sample in the FLASHE study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate barriers and facilitators for adherence to a nutritional intervention promoting fruit and vegetable consumption.
results_summary: The study found an average adherence rate of 58.3%, with high adherence associated with factors like aging, body satisfaction, and long-term program attendance. Facilitators included service structure and family support, while barriers included work and caregiving responsibilities.
population_specificity: Participants from the Health Academy Program in Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil (n=1483).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of various decontamination methods for removing pathogens and pesticides from fresh fruits and vegetables.
results_summary: The study found that simple household washing is ineffective, while modern techniques like cold plasma and ozone showed better efficacy in removing contaminants, though high costs limit industrial use. Combined methods were suggested for cost-effective and enhanced food safety.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on fresh fruits and vegetables).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the adoption and reach of a statewide intervention (Change the Future West Virginia) designed to enhance access to fresh fruits and vegetables in schools, farmers markets, and retail food outlets, particularly in food deserts.
results_summary: The intervention successfully implemented policy, system, and environment (PSE) changes, resulting in increased access to fresh fruits and vegetables across schools, farmers markets, and retail stores, reaching 21.5% of people in food desert census tracts. Key facilitators included personnel consistency, local connections, and in-person meetings.
population_specificity: Low-income communities in West Virginia, including schools, farmers markets, and retail food outlets in 48 counties.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a cooking workshop ("Art on a Plate") on children's liking and willingness to eat a spinach-fruit salad.
results_summary: The workshop led to a small increase in liking and person control, a decrease in hunger, and 30% of children increased their liking scores. Salad intake was associated with changes in liking.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-14 years (mean age 8.6) from 14 countries in Asia, America, and Europe.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an enantioselective method for quantifying permethrin (PM) enantiomers in fruits and vegetables to improve detection and control in agri-food products.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a sensitive and efficient method using SUPRAS-RAM extraction and chiral LC-MS/MS, achieving quick extraction (5 min) with high recoveries (93-107%) and low quantification limits (1.0-1.2 μg kg-1). The method avoids sample cleanup and reduces solvent consumption.
population_specificity: Agri-food products (fruits and vegetables)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a systematic introduction of taste portions and a protein-reduced complementary diet based on Nordic foods could increase fruit and vegetable intake in infants while maintaining growth and iron status.
results_summary: The Nordic diet group (NG) had significantly higher fruit and vegetable intake (225 ± 109 g/day) compared to the conventional diet group (156 ± 77 g/day) at 9 months, with no adverse effects on growth or iron status. Protein intake was lower in the NG but compensated by higher carbohydrate intake from fruits and vegetables.
population_specificity: Healthy, term infants (n = 250) aged 4-9 months, initially breast- or formula-fed.
effective_dosage: Home-made purées of Nordic produce for 24 days (4-6 months), followed by baby food products and recipes with reduced protein content (6-9 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether an eight-week, mentor-led text-messaging intervention could improve fruit and vegetable intake among rural adolescents.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased self-reported fruit and vegetable intake by 1.28 servings/day compared to controls, with no effect on beverage intake. It also improved goal-setting for healthier dietary behaviors.
population_specificity: Rural adolescents aged 14–16 years from eight high schools in eastern Kentucky and eastern North Carolina.
effective_dosage: Not specified (text messages sent twice weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of policy, systems, and environmental (PSE) changes on improving the nutritional quality of foods distributed by food pantries, particularly the distribution of fresh fruits and vegetables (FFVs).
results_summary: The study found significant increases in the distribution of calories per household (from 20,256.38 to 25,108.46) and servings of FFVs per person per household (from 0.22 to 3.33) after implementing PSE interventions in food pantries.
population_specificity: Food pantry clients in northwest Arkansas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of magnetic multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MMWCNTs) as an adsorbent for preconcentrating chiral pesticide residues in lettuce, cabbage, and apple.
results_summary: The study found that MMWCNTs effectively preconcentrated chiral pesticide residues with good enantiomeric separation (Rs > 1.48), linearity (r² > 0.9923), and recoveries (73.4% to 110.9%). The method showed repeatability (RSDr < 7.6%) and a limit of quantification of 0.10 to 0.25 mg·kg⁻¹.
population_specificity: Lettuce, cabbage, and apple samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of vouchers for fruit and vegetable (FV) purchase on FV consumption among children from disadvantaged families in a French urban district.
results_summary: After one year, the proportion of low FV consumers in children was significantly lower in the intervention group (29.4%) compared to the control group (66.7%). Overall, 82% of the vouchers were used by the families, suggesting FV vouchers could effectively increase FV consumption in disadvantaged households.
population_specificity: Children living in disadvantaged families in Saint-Denis, a suburb of Paris, France.
effective_dosage: Vouchers exchangeable for FV over a 1-year period (specific monetary value not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how sociodemographic factors, physical access, and fruit and vegetable (F&V) consumption were associated with the use of a newly opened F&V market in a disadvantaged neighborhood.
results_summary: The study found that market usage was linked to adequate F&V consumption, living closer to the market, having the market on the commute route, and not having access to a car. The market improved F&V access for low-income populations and those relying on public transportation.
population_specificity: Adults in a disadvantaged neighborhood in Montreal, Canada, including low-income individuals and those without car access.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of increasing fruit and vegetable (FV) intake on inflammatory markers and gut microbiota composition in individuals with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: The FV diet significantly decreased lipopolysaccharide binding protein (LBP) and interleukin-6 (IL-6) levels, indicating anti-inflammatory effects, and increased gut microbiota α-diversity. However, changes in microbiota composition were individualized and not consistently linked to treatment groups.
population_specificity: Forty-nine subjects with overweight or obesity and low intakes of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term impact of salad bars on fruit and vegetable selection, intake, and waste among elementary school students.
results_summary: Students selected more types of fruits and vegetables after salad bars were introduced, but actual consumption decreased. Waste also decreased due to smaller portions being selected.
population_specificity: Title I elementary school students (grades 1-5; >95% African American) in central Virginia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the levels of perfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) in locally-grown and imported fruits and vegetables and assess their potential impact on human dietary exposure.
results_summary: The study found that PFASs were detected in less than 10% of the 55 samples analyzed, with PFBA being the major contributor. PFOA was the most frequently detected compound, and the origin and growing region were identified as potential factors influencing PFAS levels.
population_specificity: Locally-grown and imported fruits and vegetables collected in 2016.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the salicylic acid (SA) content in popular vegetables and fruits consumed in Taiwan to help chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU) patients manage pseudoallergen intake.
results_summary: The study found SA concentrations ranging from 0.09 to 2.3 mg/kg in fresh vegetables and 0.01 to 0.48 mg/kg in fruits, providing data to guide dietary choices for CSU patients.
population_specificity: Chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU) patients in East Asia (specifically Taiwan).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study measured natural SA content, not administered dosages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of fiber-rich diets (fruits, vegetables, whole grains, or a combination) on weight loss and cardiovascular disease risk factors in overweight and obese women.
results_summary: The study found that a diet rich in whole grains led to greater reductions in weight, waist circumference, and certain CVD risk factors compared to diets rich in fruits and vegetables or a combination. However, all groups showed significant improvements in weight, waist circumference, and fasting blood sugar.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese women (N = 75)

study_goal: To examine the effect of the Virtual Sprouts intervention, an interactive mobile gardening game, on dietary intake and psychosocial determinants of dietary behavior related to fruits and vegetables in minority youth.
results_summary: The intervention improved self-efficacy to eat and cook fruits and vegetables but did not significantly affect dietary intake or self-efficacy to garden.
population_specificity: 180 third-, fourth-, and fifth-grade students in Los Angeles Unified School District.
effective_dosage: Three Virtual Sprouts gaming sessions, three in-school lessons, and three in-home activities over 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 2-day cooking intervention for parents of infants would improve toddlers' fruit and vegetable intake and reduce food skepticism.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in fruit and vegetable consumption or sweet beverage intake between the intervention and control groups at 15 and 24 months. The intervention also did not reduce food skepticism among toddlers.
population_specificity: Parents of 4-6 month old infants.
study_duration: 2-day intervention, with follow-up at 6, 15, and 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a supermarket double-dollar fruit and vegetable (F&V) incentive increased F&V purchases among low-income families.
results_summary: The intervention increased weekly F&V spending, particularly for fresh F&V, with the greatest increases seen among SNAP-eligible participants. The coupon redemption rate was moderate (53%), but the incentive was effective in boosting healthy purchases.
population_specificity: Low-income and SNAP-eligible supermarket customers in a rural Maine community.
effective_dosage: Half-off coupon for eligible fresh, frozen, or canned F&V at checkout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a high-protein, energy-restricted diet rich in carotenoids and polyphenols from fruits and vegetables on body composition, muscle strength, physical performance, and quality of life in overweight and obese older adults.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a randomized controlled trial design but does not report results, as it appears to be a pre-intervention outline. The intended outcomes include assessing appendicular skeletal muscle, body weight, fat-free mass, fat mass, muscle strength, physical performance, and quality of life after a 12-week intervention.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling, healthy overweight and obese older adults (≥60 years).
effective_dosage: 375 g/d of high carotenoid vegetables, 300 g/d high carotenoid fruit, and 40-60 ml extra-virgin olive oil (EVOO) or 375 g/d of lower carotenoid vegetables, 300 g/d lower carotenoid fruit, and 40-60 ml PUFA-based oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between food security status, home availability of a variety of fruits and vegetables (F&V), and the frequency of F&V intake among low-income pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found that lower food security was associated with reduced variety of F&V available at home, which in turn was linked to lower daily intake of F&V. Mediation analyses showed that food security status indirectly affected F&V intake through the availability of fresh F&V.
population_specificity: Low-income pregnant women (n=198) in their second trimester, aged ≥18, who spoke English or Spanish.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of alternative postharvest treatments for fresh-cut fruits and vegetables compared to chlorine-based methods.
results_summary: The study found that mechanical processing of fresh produce can promote microbial growth and reduce shelf life, while chlorine, though effective, poses health risks due to carcinogenic byproducts. Alternative treatments like ozone, electrolyzed water, and UV radiation achieved similar microbial reduction without harmful effects or quality compromise.
population_specificity: Minimally processed fresh-cut fruits and vegetables.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between preconception intake of pesticide residues in fruits and vegetables (FVs) and outcomes of infertility treatment with assisted reproductive technologies (ART).
results_summary: Higher intake of high-pesticide residue FVs was associated with lower probabilities of clinical pregnancy and live birth, while low-pesticide residue FV intake showed no significant effect on ART outcomes.
population_specificity: 325 women undergoing infertility treatment at a fertility center in a teaching hospital (mean age 35.1 years).
effective_dosage: Mean intake of high-pesticide residue FVs was 1.7 servings/day; low-pesticide residue FVs was 2.8 servings/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the scientific literature on the additive and synergistic effects of phytochemical mixtures in fruits and vegetables, focusing on their potential health benefits and disease prevention mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that mixtures of phytochemicals in fruits and vegetables exhibit additive and synergistic effects on cell proliferation, apoptosis, antioxidant capacity, and tumor incidence, with promising results from human dietary intervention studies. Combining transcriptomic data with phenotypic markers provided insights into the cellular processes contributing to these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature, including in vitro systems and some human dietary intervention studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of thermal and nonthermal processing methods on flavonoid content, stability, bioavailability, and cytotoxicity in fruits and vegetables.
results_summary: The study found that nonthermal processing methods better retain beneficial flavonoid content in fruits and vegetables compared to thermal methods, enhancing nutritional value and shelf life. Flavonoids demonstrated positive health effects and disease protection, with stability and bioavailability varying by processing technique.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on fruits and vegetables as food products).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a web-based school nutrition intervention (Team Nutriathlon) on promoting the consumption of vegetables and fruit (V/F) and milk and alternatives (M/A) among high school students.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant short-term increase of 3 servings per day of V/F and 1.8 servings per day of M/A compared to the control group, though effects were not sustained long-term. Facilitators of success included the team aspect, technology use, and recording results outside class.
population_specificity: First and second year secondary students (grades 7 and 8) from the Québec City region.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the level of pesticide residues in commonly consumed fruits and vegetables in Kuwait.
results_summary: 21% of samples had pesticide residues above maximum residue limits (MRL), with multiple residues detected in 40% of samples. Sixteen pesticides were identified, with eight exceeding MRLs, indicating potential health risks.
population_specificity: Commonly consumed fruits and vegetables in Kuwait.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile evidence on the antiulcer effects of fruits and vegetables and their underlying mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that fruits and vegetables combat gastric ulcers through multiple mechanisms, including antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial activities, with phytochemicals like phenolics and flavonoids playing a key role. The abstract suggests these natural remedies may offer safer and more effective alternatives to conventional treatments.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing evidence).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial potential of acetic, citric, and lactic acids against E. coli and Salmonella sp. on fresh fruits and vegetables, including their effects on biofilm formation and quorum sensing.
results_summary: The study found that lactic acid was most effective, with a 1 log reduction in microbial count on cucumbers over 6 days. Organic acids also inhibited biofilm formation and quorum sensing, with lactic acid showing the highest anti-quorum sensing potential (37.7% inhibition of violacein production).
population_specificity: Microbial pathogens (E. coli and Salmonella sp.) on fresh fruits and vegetables, specifically tested on cucumber surfaces.
effective_dosage: Minimum inhibitory concentrations: acetic acid (1.5-2%), citric acid (1.5-2%), lactic acid (0.2-1%). Treatment dosage: 2% lactic acid.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a rapid, sensitive, and efficient method for detecting multiple pesticide residues in fruits and vegetables.
results_summary: The optimized QuEChERS-UPLC-MS/MS method demonstrated high sensitivity, accuracy, and efficiency in detecting 54 pesticide residues, with good linearity, recovery rates, and low detection limits. The method was deemed suitable for high-throughput screening of pesticide residues in fruits and vegetables.
population_specificity: Three fruits and three vegetables produced in Shanghai.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between supermarket proximity and the frequency of fruit and vegetable provision in English nurseries.
results_summary: Nurseries farthest from supermarkets had 2.38 times greater odds of infrequent fruit and vegetable provision (<2-3 times/week). The study suggests that supermarket access may influence nurseries' ability to meet dietary guidelines for fruits and vegetables.
population_specificity: 623 English nurseries

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how increasing household availability of sodas and cookies influenced the effects of an intervention promoting fruit and vegetable consumption.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased household availability of fruits and vegetables (+2.7 p.p.), but families that increased purchases of sodas and cookies showed lower increases or decreases in fruit and vegetable availability.
population_specificity: 70 families from low-income communities in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of bacteriophage therapy as an antimicrobial strategy for controlling E. coli O157:H7 contamination in fruits and vegetables.
results_summary: The study found that phage therapy, applied via spraying or immersion, shows promise in reducing E. coli O157:H7 contamination in fruits and vegetables, though more ecological understanding is needed to improve effectiveness. Commercial phage products have been launched, indicating practical potential.
population_specificity: Fruits and vegetables contaminated with E. coli O157:H7.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a corner store conversion intervention (Proyecto MercadoFRESCO) in increasing access to and purchasing of fruits and vegetables (F&V) in two Latino communities.
results_summary: The intervention improved patrons' perceptions of corner stores and increased F&V purchasing during store visits, but did not significantly affect store patronage, weekly spending on F&V, or daily F&V consumption. The findings suggest limited overall impact of the intervention.
population_specificity: Store patrons in East Los Angeles and Boyle Heights, California, USA (primarily Latino communities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether polyphenol supplementation from fruits and vegetables improves muscle mass, strength, and physical performance in individuals with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant positive effect of polyphenols on muscle mass, no effect on muscle strength, and a near-significant trend for improved physical performance in sarcopenic subjects.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older individuals with sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implementation of a school-based food co-op program (Brighter Bites) combined with nutrition education to improve access to and intake of fresh fruits and vegetables among low-income children and their families.
results_summary: Brighter Bites successfully distributed an average of 60.2 servings of fresh fruits and vegetables per family per week and highlighted key lessons such as leveraging existing infrastructure, early engagement, and tracking strategies to optimize participation. The program was implemented across 9 schools, serving 1530 predominantly low-income families.
population_specificity: Low-income children and their families in a school-based setting.
effective_dosage: 60.2 servings of fresh fruits and vegetables per family per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between dietary acid load (DAL), estimated by potential renal acid load (PRAL), and mortality in patients on maintenance hemodialysis (MHD), with a focus on the role of fruits and vegetables.
results_summary: Higher PRAL scores were significantly associated with increased all-cause mortality and lower intake of green and yellow vegetables and fruits. The highest PRAL tertile had a 3.88-fold higher mortality risk compared to the lowest tertile.
population_specificity: Japanese patients on maintenance hemodialysis (44 participants, 26 men, mean age 67.9 ± 10.4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fruit and vegetable consumption on memory and attention through a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found that fruit and vegetable intake improved memory and attention, particularly in longitudinal studies (10-12 weeks). Children showed better immediate recall with blueberry supplementation, while older adults required higher doses for significant improvement.
population_specificity: Children, younger adults, and older adults.
effective_dosage: Higher doses for older adults (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the bioactivity effects, supplementation, and consumption of polyphenols found in fruits and vegetables, as well as strategies to improve their bioavailability.
results_summary: The study highlights that polyphenols in fruits and vegetables have multiple beneficial bioactive roles but suffer from limited bioavailability. Strategies like liposomal and nanoparticle formulations are being developed to enhance their absorption.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess rutin-induced hormetic concentration/dose responses, their quantitative features, mechanistic basis, and implications for biological, biomedical, clinical, and public health contexts.
results_summary: The study found that rutin-induced hormetic dose responses are widespread across various biological models and cell types, but optimal effects observed in vitro are not achievable in humans due to low gastrointestinal bioavailability.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad human consumption context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of dietary anthocyanins from fruits and vegetables on diabetes-related outcomes, including glucose regulation and inflammation reduction.
results_summary: The study found that anthocyanin supplementation improved fasting blood glucose levels, glycated hemoglobin, and other diabetes-related indicators, with higher dosages showing more favorable effects. An anthocyanin-rich diet was associated with better diabetes outcomes, particularly in at-risk groups.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: Increased dosages were noted as more effective, but specific amounts and frequencies were not provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess quercetin-induced hormetic dose responses, their quantitative features, mechanistic foundations, and implications for biological, biomedical, clinical, and public health contexts.
results_summary: The study found that quercetin-induced hormetic dose responses are widespread across biological models, cell types, and endpoints, suggesting potential benefits for future experimental designs and public health evaluations.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad biological models and cell types).
effective_dosage: Dietary intake (10-20 mg/day), supplement dosage (250-1000 mg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically appraise the current evidence for dietary nitrate supplementation (associated with fruits and vegetables) in improving brain health and suggest future research directions.
results_summary: The study found that dietary nitrate, linked to fruits and vegetables, has protective effects on vascular outcomes like blood pressure and endothelial function, but evidence for its benefits on brain health is less convincing.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms of quercetin's pharmacological activity and its role in protecting against testicular damage, as well as its clinical applications in regulating blood pressure and inhibiting cellular senescence.
results_summary: The study found that quercetin exhibits protective effects on reproductive function, likely due to its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-apoptotic properties. Clinical trials also demonstrated its practical benefits in blood pressure regulation and cellular senescence inhibition, though further research is needed to confirm its full potential.
population_specificity: Human patients (clinical trials) and general discussion of testicular damage mechanisms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the nutritional activities of luteolin, a flavonoid found in fruits and vegetables, in improving obesity and associated metabolic diseases by targeting adipose tissue energy metabolism, immunoregulation, and endocrine function.
results_summary: The study found that luteolin supplementation inhibits adipose tissue lipogenesis and inflammation, reduces ectopic lipid deposition, increases thermogenesis and energy expenditure, and improves obesity-related metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on obesity and metabolic diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the proof-of-concept of a (poly)phenolic supplementation designed to enhance daily intake of bioactive compounds from fruits and vegetables.
results_summary: The study suggests that (poly)phenol-rich supplementation could help fill the nutritional gap in the general population's intake of fruits and vegetables, potentially protecting against non-communicable diseases. However, specific efficacy results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: General population (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of antioxidant supplementation (vitamin E and C) on athletic performance and adaptations, comparing it to consuming a diet rich in fruits and vegetables.
results_summary: The study found that antioxidant supplementation may impair adaptations to resistance training by blocking anabolic signaling pathways, while a diet rich in fruits and vegetables is recommended for meeting vitamin E and C needs without negative effects.
population_specificity: Athletes, particularly those training at altitude or seeking short-term performance enhancement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the impact of the Packed Promise intervention, which included home-delivered food boxes and a check for purchasing fruits and vegetables, on improving diet quality among low-income children.
results_summary: The intervention led to small but statistically significant increases in children's daily consumption of fruits and vegetables (2.35 vs. 2.25 cup equivalents) and whole grains (0.73 vs. 0.67 ounce equivalents) compared to the control group. Other outcomes, such as food shopping frequency and family dinners, were not significantly affected.
population_specificity: Low-income children in 12 rural Oklahoma counties within Chickasaw Nation territory.
effective_dosage: $15 check for purchasing fruits and vegetables weekly, alongside a $38 food value box.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the Packed Promise intervention, which included a $15 check for purchasing fruits and vegetables, reduced child food insecurity in low-income households.
results_summary: The intervention did not significantly reduce child food insecurity but reduced adult food insecurity by 3 percentage points at 12 months and lowered household food expenditures by $27 and $16 at 12 and 18 months, respectively.
population_specificity: Low-income households with children eligible for free school meals in rural Oklahoma.
effective_dosage: $15 monthly check for purchasing fruits and vegetables.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the most effective method (dietary advice vs. potassium supplements) for increasing potassium intake to reduce blood pressure and the need for blood pressure-lowering medicines.
results_summary: The study proposed a two-stage clinical trial to evaluate tailored dietary advice and potassium supplements for increasing potassium intake, with final measurements at 52 weeks to assess persistence. The results will help determine the efficacy of dietary changes versus supplements in managing blood pressure.
population_specificity: Participants with high blood pressure and proven low potassium intake (measured via 24-h urine collection).
effective_dosage: Not specified (supplement dosage to be determined if dietary advice fails).
study_duration: 52 weeks (with interim measurements at 4 and 8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a dietary regimen combining ketogenic breakfast, lauric acid-rich MCTs, intermittent fasting, and a dinner rich in fruits and vegetables as a prophylactic and adjunct therapy against SARS-CoV-2.
results_summary: The study suggests that a diet including fruits and vegetables as part of a broader dietary strategy (ketogenic breakfast, MCTs, and intermittent fasting) may help combat SARS-CoV-2 by altering host metabolism and suppressing viral replication. However, the abstract does not isolate the specific effects of fruits and vegetables alone.
population_specificity: General population and infected individuals (not specified further).
effective_dosage: Dinner rich with fruits and vegetables (no specific amounts or frequencies provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer and anti-inflammatory properties of pterostilbene, a natural compound found in blueberries, and its potential role in cancer chemoprevention and chemotherapy.
results_summary: Pterostilbene demonstrated significant anti-inflammatory and anticancer effects, including detoxification, apoptosis enhancement, autophagy, and inhibition of tumor angiogenesis and metastasis, with higher bioavailability and lower toxicity compared to resveratrol.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on cancer chemoprevention and therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if leafy green vegetables lower blood pressure in subjects with elevated BP and whether this effect is linked to their nitrate content.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in ambulatory systolic blood pressure after 5 weeks of dietary supplementation with leafy green vegetables or nitrate pills, compared to a placebo. The changes in blood pressure were minimal and not statistically different between the groups.
population_specificity: 243 subjects aged 50-70 years with clinic systolic blood pressure of 130-159 mm Hg.
effective_dosage: 300 mg nitrate daily (either from leafy green vegetables or nitrate pills).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the therapeutic effects of ascorbic acid (from fruits, vegetables, or supplements) on periodontal disease in patients with diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: Decreased vitamin C levels were observed in PD-DM patients, but the efficacy of vitamin C administration was inconclusive. The study highlights the need for further research on ascorbic acid supplementation in this population.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontal disease and diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: 500 mg/day for 2 months and 450 mg/day for 2 weeks (supplementation); guava fruits (alimentation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify multinational surveillance systems assessing diet and nutrition in adolescents, including methods used to evaluate dietary intake such as fruits and vegetables.
results_summary: The study found variability in dietary assessment methods across 13 surveillance systems, with some focusing on limited food items like fruits and vegetables, while others omitted specific adolescent foods like fast food or snacks.
population_specificity: Adolescents in Europe, USA, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand.

study_goal: The abstract does not specify a study goal regarding fruits and vegetables.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that quercetin is found in fruits and vegetables and is marketed as a dietary supplement, but it does not report any study results on its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified
effective_dosage: Up to 1000 mg daily (for isolated quercetin supplements)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a plant-based, multi-vitamin/mineral, and phytonutrient (PMP) supplementation could improve antioxidant capacity and prevent DNA damage in healthy adults with low fruit and vegetable intake.
results_summary: PMP supplementation for eight weeks reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) and prevented DNA damage without altering the endogenous antioxidant system. Plasma vitamins and phytonutrients were significantly correlated with ROS scavenging and DNA damage, and gene expression analysis showed subtle changes in superoxide metabolic processes.
population_specificity: Healthy adults habitually low in fruit and vegetable consumption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of fruit-derived polyphenols on exercise performance and recovery, focusing on antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and vascular mechanisms.
results_summary: Acute supplementation (~300 mg polyphenols) may enhance endurance and sprint performance via antioxidant and vascular effects, while prolonged supplementation (>1000 mg/day) appears to improve recovery from muscle damage through anti-inflammatory and antioxidant actions. However, limited studies and methodological constraints warrant further research.
population_specificity: Individuals engaging in endurance or repeated sprint exercise, and those recovering from muscle damage induced by intensive exercise.
effective_dosage: ~300 mg 1-2 hours pre-exercise for performance; >1000 mg/day for 3+ days pre- and post-exercise for recovery.
study_duration: Acute (single dose) for performance; ≥3 days for recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of dietary interventions, including fruits and vegetables, in managing inflammatory bowel disease.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that diets low in fruits and vegetables are associated with new-onset inflammatory bowel disease, but it does not provide specific results on the efficacy of increasing their intake. Few well-designed clinical trials have been conducted to establish optimal dietary interventions.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of inflammatory bowel disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between fruit and vegetable consumption and bladder cancer risk, considering factors like preparation methods and genetic influences.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent results regarding the association between fruit/vegetable consumption and bladder cancer risk, though a diet rich in fruits and vegetables may convey some protective effects when combined with reduced processed meat intake and smoking cessation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antioxidant activity (AA) of dietary supplements derived from fruits and vegetables and assess how in vitro digestion affects their AA.
results_summary: The study found that antioxidant activity varied significantly among supplements, with pomegranate showing the highest AA before digestion. Digestion altered AA differently across supplements, increasing it for some (e.g., pomegranate, resveratrol) and decreasing it for others (e.g., green tea, grape seed).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multi-micronutrient supplement (MP) could protect against oxidative damage and maintain endogenous antioxidant defense in individuals with low fruit and vegetable intake.
results_summary: The MP supplement significantly increased serum folate, reduced DNA damage, and decreased LDL oxidation compared to placebo, without weakening endogenous antioxidant defense mechanisms. Serum folate levels were negatively correlated with DNA damage but not with LDL oxidation.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects with habitually low dietary fruit and vegetable intake.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether eating 5 or more servings of fruits and vegetables per day, as part of a composite periconceptional behavior index, differed among adolescent age groups and whether pregnancy intention influenced these behaviors.
results_summary: The study found that younger adolescents (13-15 years) were less likely to engage in some unhealthy behaviors but also less likely to take folic acid. Among older teens (18-19 years), intended pregnancy predicted a higher composite behavior score, which included fruit and vegetable consumption.
population_specificity: Adolescent mothers (ages 13-19) who delivered live infants during 1997-2007, part of the National Birth Defects Prevention Study control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of antioxidant-rich fruits and vegetables and supplements for improving vision health across various eye diseases.
results_summary: Antioxidant-rich fruits and vegetables showed potential benefits for protecting against glaucoma and age-related macular degeneration (AMD), but results were mixed for other conditions like diabetic retinopathy and cataract. Supplements were generally ineffective for eye infections and uveitis.
population_specificity: General population with a focus on individuals at risk for or experiencing vision health deterioration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of guided imagery on postoperative pain and comfort in geriatric orthopedic patients.
results_summary: Guided imagery significantly reduced pain levels and improved perceived comfort in the experimental group compared to baseline, while the control group showed no significant changes in comfort.
population_specificity: Geriatric patients receiving treatment at an orthopedics and traumatology inpatient clinic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine demographic, social, and economic differences in self-reported pain among racially diverse women with fibromyalgia undergoing a 10-week guided imagery intervention.
results_summary: Black women and low-income earners experienced significantly higher pain severity and interference, with a lower response to the guided imagery intervention compared to White women and higher-income earners. Disparities persisted over time despite controlling for various factors.
population_specificity: Racially diverse women with fibromyalgia (21 Black and 51 White women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of guided imagery on postoperative pain management in patients undergoing lower extremity surgery.
results_summary: Guided imagery significantly reduced postoperative pain in the intervention group (mean VAS score 2.56) compared to the control group (mean VAS score 4.10), with a statistically significant difference (p < .001). The study concluded that guided imagery effectively reduces short-term postoperative pain after lower extremity surgery.
population_specificity: 60 patients who underwent lower extremity surgery.
